The basic ideas¶

Want a representation of the board.

cell = {'x', 'y', 'drone':bool, 'player':PID, 'base':PID}

class Cell[source]

Cell(x, y, drone=False, player=None, base=None)

Represent a cell on the game board

# Test is_occupied
c  = Cell(1, 1)
c.player = 123
assert(c.is_occupied())
c.player = None
assert(c.is_occupied() == False) 

# Test is_free
c  = Cell(1, 1)
assert(c.is_free()) 
c.player = 123
assert(c.is_free() == False)
c.player = None
c.drone = True
assert(c.is_free() == False) 
c.drone = None
c.base = 1
assert(c.is_free() == False)

dice[source]

dice()

There is some explanation here, and an example:

dice()

6
# assert say_hello("Jeremy")=="Hello Jeremy!" # Test function

import math
math.ceil(5.5)

6

class Board[source]

Board()

# Create a board
b = Board()

# Add some bases and draw starting setup
b.board[0][0].player = 1
b.board[0][0].base = 1 
b.board[7][7].player = 2
b.board[7][7].base = 2
b.board[3][3].drone = True
b.show()

print('next')

b.move(1, (0, 0), (1, 1), 1)
b.show()
b.move(1, (1, 1), (6, 6), 4)
b.show()
b.move(1, (1, 1), (4, 4), 5, drone=True) # Fails  - no drone
b.show()
b.move(1, (1, 1), (3, 3), 5, drone=False) # Start from drone loc
b.move(1, (3, 3), (4, 4), 5, drone=True) # Works
b.show()
